title: Hilbert's 15th Problem
content:
**Hilbert's 15th Problem (1900)**:

> Put Schubert's enumerative calculus on rigorous foundations.

**Schubert (1879)** developed techniques for counting:
- How many lines meet 4 given lines? **2**
- How many conics tangent to 5 conics? **3264**
- How many lines on a cubic surface? **27**

**Resolution**: Intersection theory on Grassmannians (1930s-1970s)

title: The Grassmannian
content:
**Grassmannian Gr(k,n)**:

The set of all k-dimensional subspaces of an n-dimensional vector space.

$$Gr(k,n) = \{V \subseteq K^n : \dim(V) = k\}$$

**Key examples**:
- Gr(1,n) = projective (n-1)-space
- **Gr(2,4)** = lines in projective 3-space
- Gr(k,n) ≅ Gr(n-k,n) (duality)

title: Lines in P³
content:
**Lines in Projective 3-Space**:

A line in P³ corresponds to a 2-dimensional subspace of K⁴.

$$\text{LineInP}^3 = Gr(2,4)$$

**Two lines meet** iff their 2D subspaces have nontrivial intersection.

Equivalently: their span has dimension < 4 (rather than 4).

title: The Four Lines Theorem
content:
**THE CLASSIC RESULT**:

Given 4 lines in general position in P³, exactly **2 lines** meet all four!

**Proof Idea**:
1. Lines meeting L₁ and L₂ form a quadric surface Q₁₂
2. Lines meeting L₃ and L₄ form another quadric Q₃₄
3. By Bezout: Q₁₂ ∩ Q₃₄ has degree 4
4. This contains exactly 2 transversal lines

Schubert calculus: σ₁⁴ = 2σ₂₂

title: Famous Schubert Numbers
content:
**Classic Enumerative Results**:

| Problem | Answer |
|---------|--------|
| Lines meeting 4 lines | **2** |
| Lines on cubic surface | **27** |
| Conics tangent to 5 conics | **3264** |
| Conics through 5 points | **1** |

These are computed using intersection products of Schubert classes.

title: Schubert Varieties & Classes
content:
**Schubert Variety Ω_μ**:

Defined by incidence conditions with a fixed flag.

$$\Omega_\mu = \{V \in Gr(k,n) : \dim(V \cap F_{n-k+i-\mu_i}) \geq i\}$$

**Schubert Class σ_μ**: The cohomology class of Ω_μ.

**Key Facts**:
1. {σ_μ} form a ℤ-basis for H*(Gr(k,n))
2. Products given by Littlewood-Richardson rule

title: Littlewood-Richardson Rule
content:
**The Multiplication Formula**:

$$\sigma_\mu \cdot \sigma_\nu = \sum_\rho c^\rho_{\mu\nu} \sigma_\rho$$

where c^ρ_μν is the **Littlewood-Richardson coefficient** — computed combinatorially via Young tableaux.

**Pieri's Rule** (special case):
Multiplying by σ_(p) adds p boxes, no two in same column.

Conjectured 1934, proven by Schützenberger 1977.

title: Four Lines via Schubert Calculus
content:
**Schubert Calculus Verification**:

In Gr(2,4), Schubert classes are indexed by partitions in 2×2 box:
- σ₁ = lines meeting a fixed line
- σ₂₂ = point class

**The computation**:
$$\sigma_1^4 = 2 \cdot \sigma_{22}$$

This confirms: 4 general lines have exactly **2 transversals**.

title: Problem Status: SOLVED
content:
**Hilbert 15: SOLVED**

**Resolution timeline**:
- 1930s: Van der Waerden, Weil — cohomology connection
- 1934-73: Ehresmann, Chevalley, BGG — basis theorem
- 1977: Schützenberger — LR rule proof
- 1984: Fulton — complete intersection theory

**Modern extensions**:
- Quantum cohomology
- K-theory Schubert calculus
- Equivariant cohomology
